articles.headline: T-Mobile Looks to Buy MetroPCS
articles.snippet: Deutsche Telekom said on Tuesday that it was in talks to buy MetroPCS and merge it with its T-Mobile USA unit, as the German telecommunications giant sought to bolster its flagging business in the United States.
articles.abstract: Deutsche Telekom said on Tuesday that it was in talks to buy MetroPCS and merge it with its T-Mobile USA unit, as the German telecommunications giant sought to bolster its flagging business in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: 9:06 p.m. | Updated The parent company of T-Mobile USA, the struggling cellphone service provider, is in talks to buy MetroPCS  as it fights to compete against two bigger rivals.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Auto Sales Are Highest in 4 Years
articles.snippet: Many of the gains came at Toyota and Honda, the two big Japanese manufacturers that suffered major product shortages after last year’s earthquake and tsunami in Japan.
articles.abstract: Many of the gains came at Toyota and Honda, the two big Japanese manufacturers that suffered major product shortages after last year’s earthquake and tsunami in Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Unemployment is still high and the so-called fiscal cliff is looming, but those worries didn’t slow down the nation’s car and truck buyers in September.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Tracking Killers in Attack on Libya Mission
articles.snippet: Military and counterterrorism teams are preparing dossiers in the first step toward preparing for orders from President Obama.
articles.abstract: Military and counterterrorism teams are preparing dossiers in the first step toward preparing for orders from President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is laying the groundwork for operations to kill or capture militants implicated in the deadly attack on a diplomatic mission in Libya, senior military and counterterrorism officials said Tuesday, as the weak Libyan government appears unable to arrest or even question fighters involved in the assault.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Sites That Pay the Shopper for Being a Seller
articles.snippet: Social media shopping sites are offering payments to shoppers who post product links that drive Web traffic and sales to retailers.
articles.abstract: Social media shopping sites are offering payments to shoppers who post product links that drive Web traffic and sales to retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Julie Medeiros thinks her taste in fashion is worth something. Turns out it is: about $50 a month.

articles.headline: Health Care as Income for the Poor
articles.snippet: The Congressional Budget Office for the first time included health benefits in its reports on income, renewing a debate about how much health care is really worth to poor families.
articles.abstract: The Congressional Budget Office for the first time included health benefits in its reports on income, renewing a debate about how much health care is really worth to poor families.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a nation, we devote almost one-sixth of our spending to health care, twice the share of 30 years ago. Medical bills for the elderly are climbing, threatening to blow up the budget in a few decades. Politicians from both parties are consumed by how to pay for it all. Yet we cannot quite agree on how valuable government health care benefits are to Americans.

articles.headline: Ads Attack Wall Street Ties, No Matter How Flimsy
articles.snippet: Candidates are trying to gain an edge by linking their opponents to bailouts and banking, no matter how flimsy the connection may be.
articles.abstract: Candidates are trying to gain an edge by linking their opponents to bailouts and banking, no matter how flimsy the connection may be.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street has taken a beating this election season. Yet what is considered to be Wall Street may be surprising.

articles.headline: Iran’s Master of Iraq Chaos Still Vexes U.S.
articles.snippet: Qassim Suleimani, a general in the Quds Force of the Revolutionary Guards, is linked to many aspects of both war and diplomacy in classified documents.
articles.abstract: Qassim Suleimani, a general in the Quds Force of the Revolutionary Guards, is linked to many aspects of both war and diplomacy in classified documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a senior Iraqi intelligence official traveled to Tehran in the summer of 2007 to meet with the Iranian leadership, he quickly figured out who was in charge of Iran’s policy toward its neighbor to the west.

articles.headline: Stark Backdrop as President Prepares to Debate
articles.snippet: While preparing in Nevada for his debate with Mitt Romney, President Obama need only look outside for a reminder that the economy has yet to fully recover.
articles.abstract: While preparing in Nevada for his debate with Mitt Romney, President Obama need only look outside for a reminder that the economy has yet to fully recover.
articles.lead_paragraph: HENDERSON, Nev. — Las Vegas might seem the last place a presidential candidate would choose to spend three days of sober, nose-to-the-grindstone debate preparation. But since Sunday, President Obama has been encamped 17 miles from the neon excess of the Strip, in a palm-fringed, financially battered lakeside resort that serves as a vivid reminder of the economic distress that still threatens his hopes for re-election.

articles.headline: Turkey Strikes Back After Syrian Shelling Kills 5 Civilians
articles.snippet: Turkey’s prime minister said Syrian targets were hit in retaliation for mortar fire that struck a Turkish town, raising the prospect of greater involvement by NATO in Syria.
articles.abstract: Turkey’s prime minister said Syrian targets were hit in retaliation for mortar fire that struck a Turkish town, raising the prospect of greater involvement by NATO in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey said Wednesday that it shelled targets within Syria as retaliation for a mortar shell that landed across the Turkish border and killed five civilians, a move that increases the risk of escalating the bloody civil war into a regional conflict and ratchets up pressure for further international involvement.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: Japan’s New Tech Generation
articles.snippet: While Japan’s aging technology giants continue to falter, entrepreneurs are forming start-ups despite difficulties with financing and a culture that discourages risk-taking.
articles.abstract: While Japan’s aging technology giants continue to falter, entrepreneurs are forming start-ups despite difficulties with financing and a culture that discourages risk-taking.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Every Wednesday, a bar in central Tokyo hosts an unusual speed-dating event. There are drinks and plenty of coy looks. But the young people at the bar aren’t here for romance.

articles.headline: Fan Sites Settle Children’s Privacy Charges
articles.snippet: Federal authorities had accused Artist Arena, the operator of Web sites for stars like Justin Bieber and Selena Gomez, of illegally collecting information on thousands of children.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities had accused Artist Arena, the operator of Web sites for stars like Justin Bieber and Selena Gomez, of illegally collecting information on thousands of children.
articles.lead_paragraph: The operator of fan Web sites for the pop stars Justin Bieber, Selena Gomez, Rihanna and Demi Lovato agreed to pay a $1 million civil penalty to settle federal charges that the sites illegally collected personal information about thousands of children, the Federal Trade Commission said Wednesday.
